Amendment to "A Bill for the Further Prosecution of the Illinois and Michigan Canal,"
               [22 January 1840]1 Amendment of the select committee— Amend the eighth section by adding there to the following towit."norshallupon any contracts except those existing at the passage of this
               act."Providedthat contracts which may be transfered from one
               contractor to another, without any change in their terms, shall not be construed to
               be new contracts2
paragraphs:
Amendment to "A Bill for the Further Prosecution of the Illinois and Michigan Canal,"
               [22 January 1840]1

Amend the eighth section by adding there to the following towit."norshallupon any contracts except those existing at the passage of this
               act."Providedthat contracts which may be transfered from one
               contractor to another, without any change in their terms, shall not be construed to
               be new contracts2
citations: Illinois HouseJournal. 1839. 11th G. A., special sess., 136, 163, 201, 204, 232-33, 235, 236, 242-43.

footnotes.text: 1Abraham Lincoln wrote the text of this amendment and the docketing on the back page.

2On January 22, 1840, Lincoln of a select committee proposed this amendment toHB 108,  introduced byNewton Cloudin theHouse of Representativeson January 8. On January 13, the House referred the bill to the Committee on the
                  Judiciary. The Committee on the Judiciary reported back the bill on January 18 with
                  an amendment, in which the House concurred. The House refused to order the bill engrossed
                  for a third reading by a vote of 35 yeas to 50 nays, with Lincoln voting yea. On January
                  20, the House re-considered this vote and, upon Lincoln’s motion, referred the bill
                  to a five-person select committee that included Lincoln. Lincoln of the select committee
                  reported back the bill on January 22 with this amendment. Representatives offered
                  amendments, and the House informally tabled the bill and proposed amendments. On January
                  23, the House tabled the amendment to the select committee’s amendment and concurred
                  with the select committee’s amendment. The House added language related to the issuance
                  of scrip, but rejected further amendment related to the issue of scrip by a vote of
                  26 yeas to 55 nays, with Lincoln voting nay. Lincoln proposed anamendmentto add a proviso to the first section, which the House adopted . On January 24, the
                  House tabled, on Lincoln’s motion, an amendment and an amendment to said amendment.
                  The House refused to order the bill engrossed for a third reading by a vote of 36
                  yeas to 46 nays, with Lincoln voting yea.Illinois HouseJournal. 1839. 11th G. A., special sess., 136, 163, 201, 204, 232-33, 235, 236, 242-43.
